# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# Split Navigation Architecture Plan

## Goal
Reorganize the site navigation to use context-aware headers/footers:
- **Marketing pages**: Full CMS-controlled navigation with CTAs
- **Portfolio pages**: Minimal chrome where the business's work is the star
- **Dashboard**: App navigation (already separate, no change needed)

## Current State

### Route Structure
```
src/app/
├── (public)/           ← PROBLEM: Mixes marketing + portfolio pages
│   ├── layout.tsx      → Uses SiteHeader + SiteFooter for ALL pages
│   ├── blog/           Marketing
│   ├── learn/          Marketing
│   ├── services/       Marketing
│   ├── tools/          Marketing
│   ├── businesses/     Portfolio (UGC) ← Should have minimal chrome
│   ├── contractors/    Portfolio (UGC) ← Legacy, re-exports businesses
│   └── [city]/masonry/ Portfolio (UGC) ← Should have minimal chrome
├── (dashboard)/        App navigation (no change needed)
├── (auth)/             Minimal (no change needed)
└── (payload)/          CMS admin (no change needed)
```

### Terminology Status
- `businesses` table is primary (canonical)
- `contractors` table maintained for backward compatibility
- Routes exist at both `/businesses/*` and `/contractors/*`
- Migration ~40% complete

---

## Proposed Architecture

### Route Group Reorganization
```
src/app/
├── (marketing)/        ← NEW: Full marketing header/footer (CMS)
│   ├── layout.tsx      → MarketingHeader + MarketingFooter
│   ├── (home)/         Landing page (needs sub-group for root path)
│   │   └── page.tsx
│   ├── blog/
│   ├── learn/
│   ├── services/
│   ├── tools/
│   ├── about/
│   ├── contact/
│   └── examples/
│
├── (portfolio)/        ← NEW: Minimal chrome for UGC pages
│   ├── layout.tsx      → PortfolioHeader + PortfolioFooter
│   ├── businesses/
│   │   ├── page.tsx    Directory listing (UGC-driven)
│   │   └── [city]/[slug]/  Individual business profile
│   ├── contractors/    Legacy redirect (can eventually remove)
│   └── [city]/         City pages (UGC-driven, cities from DB)
│       ├── page.tsx    City landing
│       └── masonry/
│           ├── page.tsx        Category in city
│           ├── [type]/page.tsx Type listings
│           ├── [type]/cost/    Cost guides
│           └── [type]/[slug]/  Individual project
│
├── (dashboard)/        No change
├── (auth)/             No change
└── (payload)/          No change
```

### Navigation Global Schema Update

Update `src/payload/globals/Navigation.ts` with split contexts:

```typescript
fields: [
  // ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
  // MARKETING NAVIGATION
  // ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
  {
    type: 'collapsible',
    label: 'Marketing Header',
    fields: [
      {
        name: 'marketingHeaderLinks',
        type: 'array',
        label: 'Header Links',
        maxRows: 8,
        fields: [
          { name: 'label', type: 'text', required: true },
          { name: 'href', type: 'text', required: true },
          { name: 'newTab', type: 'checkbox', defaultValue: false },
        ],
      },
      {
        name: 'marketingHeaderCta',
        type: 'group',
        label: 'Header CTA',
        fields: [
          { name: 'label', type: 'text', defaultValue: 'Get Started' },
          { name: 'href', type: 'text', defaultValue: '/signup' },
        ],
      },
    ],
  },
  {
    type: 'collapsible',
    label: 'Marketing Footer',
    fields: [
      {
        name: 'marketingFooterColumns',
        type: 'array',
        maxRows: 4,
        fields: [
          { name: 'title', type: 'text', required: true },
          {
            name: 'links',
            type: 'array',
            fields: [
              { name: 'label', type: 'text', required: true },
              { name: 'href', type: 'text', required: true },
            ],
          },
        ],
      },
      {
        name: 'marketingFooterLegal',
        type: 'array',
        fields: [
          { name: 'label', type: 'text' },
          { name: 'href', type: 'text' },
        ],
      },
    ],
  },

  // ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
  // PORTFOLIO NAVIGATION (Minimal chrome for business profiles)
  // ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
  {
    type: 'collapsible',
    label: 'Portfolio Pages',
    admin: {
      description: 'Minimal navigation for business profiles and project pages',
    },
    fields: [
      {
        name: 'portfolioHeaderStyle',
        type: 'select',
        defaultValue: 'minimal',
        options: [
          { label: 'Minimal (Logo + Back)', value: 'minimal' },
          { label: 'Hidden', value: 'hidden' },
        ],
      },
      {
        name: 'portfolioCta',
        type: 'group',
        label: 'Floating CTA',
        fields: [
          { name: 'enabled', type: 'checkbox', defaultValue: true },
          { name: 'label', type: 'text', defaultValue: 'Need Similar Work?' },
          { name: 'href', type: 'text', defaultValue: '/signup' },
        ],
      },
      {
        name: 'portfolioFooterText',
        type: 'text',
        defaultValue: 'Portfolio powered by KnearMe',
      },
    ],
  },
]
```

---

## Visual Design

### Marketing Pages (Full Navigation)
```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  [Logo]   Home  Blog  Learn  Services  Pricing    [Get Started] │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤

```

### Portfolio Pages (Minimal Chrome)
```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐

└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

---

## Files to Create/Modify

| File | Action | Purpose |
|------|--------|---------|
| `src/payload/globals/Navigation.ts` | Modify | Add split context fields |
| `src/lib/payload/client.ts` | Modify | Add `getMarketingNav()`, `getPortfolioNav()` |
| `src/app/(marketing)/layout.tsx` | Create | Marketing layout with CMS nav |
| `src/app/(portfolio)/layout.tsx` | Create | Portfolio layout with minimal nav |
| `src/components/marketing/MarketingHeader.tsx` | Create | CMS-driven marketing header |
| `src/components/marketing/MarketingFooter.tsx` | Create | CMS-driven marketing footer |
| `src/components/portfolio/PortfolioHeader.tsx` | Create | Minimal header (logo + back) |
| `src/components/portfolio/PortfolioFooter.tsx` | Create | Minimal footer (attribution) |
| `src/components/portfolio/FloatingCta.tsx` | Create | Optional floating CTA button |
| `src/components/portfolio/BusinessProfileHeader.tsx` | Rename | From ContractorProfileHeader |
| `src/components/portfolio/BusinessProfileSections.tsx` | Rename | From ContractorProfileSections |
| `src/components/navigation/DashboardMobileNav.tsx` | Rename | From ContractorMobileNav |

### Files to Move (Route Reorganization)

**From `(public)/` to `(marketing)/`:**
- `blog/` → `(marketing)/blog/`
- `learn/` → `(marketing)/learn/`
- `services/` → `(marketing)/services/`
- `tools/` → `(marketing)/tools/`
- `about/` → `(marketing)/about/`
- `contact/` → `(marketing)/contact/`
- `examples/` → `(marketing)/examples/`

**From `(public)/` to `(portfolio)/`:**
- `businesses/` → `(portfolio)/businesses/`
- `contractors/` → `(portfolio)/contractors/`
- `[city]/` → `(portfolio)/[city]/`

**Delete after migration:**
- `src/app/(public)/` (entire route group)

---

## Implementation Order

### Phase 1: Infrastructure (Non-breaking)
1. Update `Navigation.ts` global with new fields
2. Add query helpers to `client.ts`
3. Create new layout components (Marketing/Portfolio Header/Footer)

### Phase 2: Component Renaming
4. Rename `ContractorProfileHeader` → `BusinessProfileHeader`
5. Rename `ContractorProfileSections` → `BusinessProfileSections`
6. Rename `ContractorMobileNav` → `DashboardMobileNav`
7. Update all imports referencing renamed components

### Phase 3: Route Reorganization
8. Create `(marketing)/` route group with new layout
9. Create `(portfolio)/` route group with new layout
10. Move marketing pages to `(marketing)/`
11. Move portfolio pages to `(portfolio)/`
12. Delete old `(public)/` route group

### Phase 4: Wire Up CMS
13. Update MarketingHeader to fetch from CMS
14. Update MarketingFooter to fetch from CMS
15. Seed initial navigation content in Payload

### Phase 5: Polish
16. Add FloatingCta component for portfolio pages
17. Test all routes work correctly
18. Verify SEO (sitemaps, meta tags still work)

---

## Verification Plan

1. **Route Testing**: Verify all pages load correctly after migration
   - Marketing: `/`, `/blog`, `/learn`, `/services/*`, `/tools/*`
   - Portfolio: `/businesses/*`, `/[city]/masonry/*`
   - Dashboard: `/dashboard`, `/projects/*` (unchanged)

2. **Navigation Testing**:
   - Marketing pages show full header/footer
   - Portfolio pages show minimal header/footer
   - CMS changes reflect on site

3. **SEO Verification**:
   - Check `/sitemap.xml` includes all pages
   - Verify meta tags on portfolio pages
   - Test JSON-LD structured data

4. **Visual Check**:
   - Portfolio pages feel clean, focused on content
   - Marketing pages have clear CTAs
   - Mobile responsive on both layouts

---

## Additional Scope: Contractor → Business Renaming

As part of this work, rename components to use "Business" terminology:

| Current Name | New Name |
|--------------|----------|
| `ContractorProfileHeader.tsx` | `BusinessProfileHeader.tsx` |
| `ContractorProfileSections.tsx` | `BusinessProfileSections.tsx` |
| `ContractorMobileNav.tsx` | `DashboardMobileNav.tsx` |
| Any other `Contractor*` components | `Business*` equivalents |

**Update imports** in all files that reference renamed components.

---

## Out of Scope (Future Work)

- Deprecating `/contractors/*` routes (after traffic analysis)
- Advanced portfolio customization (custom colors per business)
- Full contractors table deprecation

# Repository Guidelines

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (see `PLANS.md` at the repository root). Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Modules
- App entry and routing live in `src/app`, with feature routes under folders like `(auth)`, `(contractor)`, and `(public)`.
- Reusable UI and feature components are in `src/components` (for example `src/components/portfolio`, `src/components/forms`, `src/components/ui`).
- Shared logic resides in `src/hooks`, `src/lib` (Supabase, SEO, utilities), and `src/types`.
- Product documentation is organized under `docs/01-vision` through `docs/10-launch`; keep architecture and decision records there.

## Architecture Overview
- Next.js App Router frontend deployed on Vercel, with Supabase providing authentication, PostgreSQL, and file storage.
- API routes and server actions live under `src/app/api` and server components; call Supabase through helpers in `src/lib/supabase`.
- Database schema changes belong in `supabase/migrations`; keep C4 diagrams and data model docs up to date in `docs/03-architecture`.

## Build, Dev, and Lint
- `npm run dev` – start the Next.js dev server.
- `npm run build` – create a production build; fix all type and lint errors before committing.
- `npm start` – run the built app locally.
- `npm run lint` – run ESLint with the Next.js core-web-vitals config; all changes should pass.

## Coding Style & Naming
- Use TypeScript throughout; prefer explicit types on public functions and shared utilities.
- Follow React/Next conventions: `PascalCase` for components, `camelCase` for variables and functions, and file-based routing under `src/app`.
- Keep components small and focused; place shared UI in `src/components/ui` and feature-specific logic in the closest feature folder.
- Respect existing Tailwind usage from `src/app/globals.css` and utility patterns (`clsx`, `tailwind-merge`).

## Testing & Quality
- Add lightweight tests or examples near complex logic (for example, utilities in `src/lib/utils.ts`).
- Before opening a PR, ensure `npm run lint` and `npm run build` succeed and that key flows in `(auth)` and `(contractor)` run locally.

## Security & Configuration
- Store secrets in `.env.local` (never commit them); required vars include `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL`, `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY`, `SUPABASE_SERVICE_ROLE_KEY`, and OpenAI API keys.
- Use the Supabase admin client from `src/lib/supabase/server.ts` only in secure server-side code, and follow `docs/06-security/threat-model.md` for RLS, rate limiting, security headers, and file-upload validation.

## Commits & Pull Requests
- Write concise, imperative commit messages (for example, `Add contractor onboarding form`, `Fix auth redirect in layout`).
- For pull requests, include: a short summary, any linked issues, screenshots or GIFs for UI changes, and notes on testing performed.
- Keep PRs focused on a single feature or fix; update relevant docs under `docs/` when behavior or architecture changes.

## Messaging Guidelines

When writing user-facing copy, marketing content, or UI text:

### Core Message
KnearMe turns finished projects into shareable proof that wins more jobs. AI handles the writing—the contractor's work is the hero.

### Voice Checklist
- [ ] Does it focus on the contractor's work, not our technology?
- [ ] Does it promise outcomes (more jobs) not features (fast/easy)?
- [ ] Would a busy contractor understand it in 3 seconds?
- [ ] Does it avoid jargon like "case study", "SEO", "AI-powered"?

### Quick Reference
- **Hero**: The contractor and their craftsmanship
- **Villain**: Competitors with better online presence stealing jobs
- **Solution**: Make every project visible proof that builds trust
- **Tone**: Direct, practical, tradesperson-friendly

payload.user_instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.user_instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# Marketing Site & SEO Implementation Plan

> **Based on:** `docs/01-vision/vision.md`, `docs/02-requirements/user-journeys.md` (J1), and `docs/02-requirements/epics/EPIC-005-seo.md`.

## Overview

The "Marketing Part" of KnearMe serves two distinct audiences effectively:
1.  **Businesses (Primary for MVP):** The **Landing Page** (`/`) must convert visitors into signups by promising effortless portfolio building.
2.  **Clients (Secondary/SEO):** The **Project Pages** (`/[city]/masonry/...`) and **Business Profiles** (`/businesses/[city]/[slug]`) act as landing pages for organic search traffic.

This plan focuses on implementing the **Business Acquisition Landing Page** and the **SEO Infrastructure** required to make the platform discoverable.

---

## Phase 1: Landing Page (Business Acquisition)
**Target Audience:** "Mike the Mason"
**Goal:** Convert visitors to Signups (Start Free).

### 1.1 Page Structure (`src/app/page.tsx`)
Based on `user-journeys.md` Screen 1.

#### Sections
1.  **Hero Section**
    -   **Headline:** "Build Your Portfolio in 30 Seconds Per Project"
    -   **Subhead:** "Upload photos, answer a few questions by voice, and AI does the rest."
    -   **CTA:** "Get Started Free" (Links to `/signup`)
    -   **Visual:** Split screen or hero image showing "Before -> After" transformation or the mobile app UI.

2.  **How It Works (The "Magic" Flow)**
    -   Visual breakdown of the 4 steps:
        1.  📸 **Upload** (Snap photos)
        2.  🎤 **Voice** (Speak to the app)
        3.  ✨ **AI** (Generates content)
        4.  ✅ **Publish** (Live portfolio)

3.  **Value Proposition Grid**
    -   "No typing required"
    -   "SEO optimized automatically"
    -   "Look professional instantly"

4.  **Social Proof / Trust**
    -   "Trusted by [X]+ Businesses"
    -   Testimonial carousel (optional for MVP, use placeholders if needed).

5.  **CTA Footer**
    -   "Ready to showcase your work?"
    -   Secondary "Get Started" button.

### 1.2 Components to Build
-   `src/components/marketing/HeroSection.tsx`
-   `src/components/marketing/FeatureGrid.tsx`
-   `src/components/marketing/HowItWorks.tsx`
-   `src/components/marketing/TrustBar.tsx`
-   `src/components/ui/cta-button.tsx` (High contrast, large touch target)

---

## Phase 2: SEO Infrastructure
**Target Audience:** Google Search Bot
**Goal:** Index all published projects and profiles.

### 2.1 Metadata Strategy (`EPIC-005-seo.md`)
Implement Next.js Metadata API in `layout.tsx` and dynamic pages.

-   **Global Metadata (`src/app/layout.tsx`)**:
    -   Default title: "KnearMe | Masonry Portfolio Platform"
    -   Default OG Image.
    -   Canonical URL formatting.

-   **Dynamic Metadata**:
    -   **Project Page**: `src/app/(public)/[city]/masonry/[type]/[slug]/page.tsx`
    -   **Profile Page**: `src/app/(public)/businesses/[city]/[slug]/page.tsx`
    -   *Action*: Implement `generateMetadata()` fetching real data from Supabase.

### 2.2 Structured Data (JSON-LD)
Implement `Script` tags with JSON-LD in dynamic pages.

-   **Project Page**: `Article` type, `ImageGallery`.
-   **Profile Page**: `LocalBusiness` type.
-   *Helper*: Create `src/lib/seo/schema-generator.ts` to map DB types to Schema.org objects.

### 2.3 Sitemap & Robots
-   **Robots.txt**: `src/app/robots.ts`
    -   Allow `/`
    -   Disallow `/dashboard`, `/api`
-   **Sitemap**: `src/app/sitemap.ts`
    -   Fetch all `published` projects.
    -   Fetch all active businesses (contractors table).
    -   Generate XML URLs dynamically.

---

## Phase 3: Public Page Layouts
Although part of "Product", these are marketing pages for the businesses.

-   **Layout**: `src/app/(public)/layout.tsx`
    -   **Header**: "KnearMe" Logo (Home link), "For Businesses" (CTA).
    -   **Footer**: Links to About, Terms, Privacy, "Build Your Portfolio".

---

## Execution Checklist
 
 ### Marketing Home
 - [x] Design & Build `HeroSection`
 - [x] Design & Build `HowItWorks` section
 - [x] Assemble `src/app/page.tsx`
 - [x] Add analytics events to "Get Started" buttons (Partially - buttons exist)
 
 ### SEO Engine
 - [x] Implement `robots.ts`
 - [x] Implement `sitemap.ts` (Dynamic fetching)
 - [x] Create `SchemaGenerator` utility (`src/lib/seo/structured-data.ts`)
 - [ ] Add `generateMetadata` to Project Page
 - [ ] Add `generateMetadata` to Contractor Profile Page

# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

payload.text:
**Assessing docs versus navigation updates**

Current docs still reference the `(public)` route group and legacy components like SiteHeader/SiteFooter, while code has added `(marketing)` and `(portfolio)` groups with new navigation structures. Doc updates are needed to align with the new routing and navigation schema, especially since the docs don't yet mention the new or deprecated navigation elements.

**Identifying specific doc mismatches with code**

Docs still reference `(public)` layouts and component names like `ContractorMobileNav` while code partially migrated to new `(marketing)` and `(portfolio)` groups and renamed components. Key doc files in architecture, marketing plan, and SEO directories mention outdated routes and layouts, confirming concrete doc updates are needed to reflect the current and planned navigation architecture.

# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

The code uses updated global navigation and static footers, while docs lack coverage of new nav fields and reference outdated route groups like `(contractor)`, causing misalignment with both current code and future plans.

**Identifying doc misalignments on route groups and data tables**

The docs incorrectly reference a `(contractor)` route group not present in code, which uses `(dashboard)` instead, and mention the `contractors` table while the code likely uses `businesses` as primary. These discrepancies require documentation updates for clarity and accuracy.

# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Noting doc and code navigation mismatches**

I found docs still reference outdated route groups like `(contractor)` and `(public)` while code uses `(dashboard)` and plans to split `(public)` into `(marketing)` and `(portfolio)`. Also, docs call "Business Profiles" but code retains contractor-themed names and routes, reflecting partial alignment but notable doc-code divergence to highlight.

**Listing docs needing route group and terminology updates**

Several docs reference old `(public)` routes and contractor terms inconsistent with upcoming `(marketing)`/`(portfolio)` splits and the shift from contractors to businesses, especially in marketing-site-plan and SEO docs. Some bug logs are outdated but low priority. Next, I'll verify sitemap code to confirm terminology used.

# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Clarifying docs vs. code terminology**

The sitemap code still relies on the contractors table, meaning docs referencing it remain accurate despite a migration plan favoring the businesses table as canonical. I'll next review docs for mismatches with current code and the ongoing plan, citing file paths and line numbers ordered by severity.

**Identifying doc misalignments with routing and navigation**

I mapped key doc issues: the AGENTS doc wrongly references a nonexistent `(contractor)` route group (high severity), many SEO and marketing docs still mention the old `(public)` route group and static layout though code now uses split `(marketing)` and `(portfolio)` groups with dynamic nav (medium severity), and missing docs for new navigation globals. I'll extract precise file paths and line numbers to report these findings.

     1	# Repository Guidelines
     2	
     3	## ExecPlans
     4	When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (see `PLANS.md` at the repository root). Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.
     5	
     6	## Project Structure & Modules
     7	- App entry and routing live in `src/app`, with feature routes under folders like `(auth)`, `(contractor)`, and `(public)`.
     8	- Reusable UI and feature components are in `src/components` (for example `src/components/portfolio`, `src/components/forms`, `src/components/ui`).
     9	- Shared logic resides in `src/hooks`, `src/lib` (Supabase, SEO, utilities), and `src/types`.
    10	- Product documentation is organized under `docs/01-vision` through `docs/10-launch`; keep architecture and decision records there.
    11	
    12	## Architecture Overview
    13	- Next.js App Router frontend deployed on Vercel, with Supabase providing authentication, PostgreSQL, and file storage.
    14	- API routes and server actions live under `src/app/api` and server components; call Supabase through helpers in `src/lib/supabase`.
    15	- Database schema changes belong in `supabase/migrations`; keep C4 diagrams and data model docs up to date in `docs/03-architecture`.
    16	
    17	## Build, Dev, and Lint
    18	- `npm run dev` – start the Next.js dev server.
    19	- `npm run build` – create a production build; fix all type and lint errors before committing.
    20	- `npm start` – run the built app locally.
    21	- `npm run lint` – run ESLint with the Next.js core-web-vitals config; all changes should pass.
    22	
    23	## Coding Style & Naming
    24	- Use TypeScript throughout; prefer explicit types on public functions and shared utilities.
    25	- Follow React/Next conventions: `PascalCase` for components, `camelCase` for variables and functions, and file-based routing under `src/app`.
    26	- Keep components small and focused; place shared UI in `src/components/ui` and feature-specific logic in the closest feature folder.
    27	- Respect existing Tailwind usage from `src/app/globals.css` and utility patterns (`clsx`, `tailwind-merge`).
    28	
    29	## Testing & Quality
    30	- Add lightweight tests or examples near complex logic (for example, utilities in `src/lib/utils.ts`).
    31	- Before opening a PR, ensure `npm run lint` and `npm run build` succeed and that key flows in `(auth)` and `(contractor)` run locally.
    32	
    33	## Security & Configuration
    34	- Store secrets in `.env.local` (never commit them); required vars include `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL`, `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY`, `SUPABASE_SERVICE_ROLE_KEY`, and OpenAI API keys.
    35	- Use the Supabase admin client from `src/lib/supabase/server.ts` only in secure server-side code, and follow `docs/06-security/threat-model.md` for RLS, rate limiting, security headers, and file-upload validation.
    36	
    37	## Commits & Pull Requests
    38	- Write concise, imperative commit messages (for example, `Add contractor onboarding form`, `Fix auth redirect in layout`).
    39	- For pull requests, include: a short summary, any linked issues, screenshots or GIFs for UI changes, and notes on testing performed.
    40	- Keep PRs focused on a single feature or fix; update relevant docs under `docs/` when behavior or architecture changes.
    41	
    42	## Messaging Guidelines
    43	
    44	When writing user-facing copy, marketing content, or UI text:
    45	
    46	### Core Message
    47	KnearMe turns finished projects into shareable proof that wins more jobs. AI handles the writing—the contractor's work is the hero.
    48	
    49	### Voice Checklist
    50	- [ ] Does it focus on the contractor's work, not our technology?
    51	- [ ] Does it promise outcomes (more jobs) not features (fast/easy)?
    52	- [ ] Would a busy contractor understand it in 3 seconds?
    53	- [ ] Does it avoid jargon like "case study", "SEO", "AI-powered"?
    54	
    55	### Quick Reference
    56	- **Hero**: The contractor and their craftsmanship
    57	- **Villain**: Competitors with better online presence stealing jobs
    58	- **Solution**: Make every project visible proof that builds trust
    59	- **Tone**: Direct, practical, tradesperson-friendly

# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

   152	```
   153	The `useIsMobile()` hook is used to gate the overlay display to mobile viewports only.
   154	
   155	---
   156	
   157	### 5. Recurring Chunk Loading Errors
   158	**Severity**: MEDIUM (development mode issue)
   159	**Status**: ⚡ KNOWN ISSUE (dev mode only)
   160	**Location**: Next.js build/chunk loading
   161	
   162	**Symptoms**:
   163	- Error: "Loading chunk app/(public)/layout failed"
   164	- Appears multiple times during session
   165	- Requires clicking "Try Again" to recover
   166	
   167	**Root Cause**:
   168	This is a common Next.js development mode issue, NOT a production bug:
   169	1. **Browser cache** - Old chunk hashes cached while dev server regenerates new ones
   170	2. **HMR conflicts** - Hot Module Reload can't update all chunks atomically
   171	3. **Multiple dev servers** - Running on alternate ports (3000 vs 3001) causes cache misses
   172	
   173	**Workaround** (development only):
   174	```bash
   175	# Clear .next cache and restart
   176	rm -rf .next && npm run dev
   177	
   178	# Or hard refresh in browser
   179	# Cmd+Shift+R (Mac) / Ctrl+Shift+R (Windows)
   180	```

# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills

- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. - skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills

payload.message:
Reviewed the plan, current app code in `apps/knearme-portfolio/src`, and docs under `apps/knearme-portfolio/docs`.

**Findings**
- High — `apps/knearme-portfolio/AGENTS.md:7,31` still references `(contractor)` routes for structure/testing. The app currently has `src/app/(dashboard)` and no `(contractor)` group, and the plan introduces `(marketing)`/`(portfolio)`. This doc will steer work to the wrong route group.
- Medium — Marketing/SEO docs still pin page paths to `app/(public)` which will be wrong after the split-navigation move: `apps/knearme-portfolio/docs/07-delivery/marketing-site-plan.md:70-73,96-97`, `apps/knearme-portfolio/docs/11-seo-discovery/README.md:40-61,71-74`, `apps/knearme-portfolio/docs/SEO-DISCOVERY-STRATEGY.md:65-70`, `apps/knearme-portfolio/docs/12-homeowner-tools/tools-hub.md:169`. These should change to `(marketing)` for marketing/tools/learn/services and `(portfolio)` for UGC pages.
- Medium — The landing-page doc still anchors `/` to `src/app/page.tsx` and the layout to `src/app/(public)/layout.tsx` (`apps/knearme-portfolio/docs/07-delivery/marketing-site-plan.md:19,96`), but the plan moves the root into `(marketing)/(home)` and adds distinct layouts.
- Low — Split navigation CMS schema and helpers are already implemented (`apps/knearme-portfolio/src/payload/globals/Navigation.ts:1-68`, `apps/knearme-portfolio/src/lib/payload/client.ts:1132-1246`), but no doc explains how to configure or consume Marketing vs Portfolio nav. Consider adding a short architecture note so docs stay in sync with this change.
- Low — The dev-issue log references `app/(public)/layout` chunk errors (`apps/knearme-portfolio/docs/testing/agent-ux-issues-2026-01-01.md:157-164`), which will become stale once routes move.

**Questions / assumptions**
- Do you want docs updated now to the planned `(marketing)/(portfolio)` structure, or keep them aligned with current `src/app/(public)` until the route move lands?
- Should I add a brief “Navigation & Route Groups” doc (or update an existing one) describing the CMS schema + route grouping?

If you want, I can update the docs in the files above.
